ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I built my own mobile application from start to finish. Specifically, I learned how to program an app in Swift and pull relevant data from Firestore.
I learned a lot about building, training, and testing deep neural networks, as well as dealing with textual datasets.
research
Ability to work independently. You know the deal.
Research
I implemented remote attestation protocol in CertiKOS kernel for inter process attestation. I learned about cryptographic primitives and guarantees.
Designing systems from scratch. Prototyping. Working with multiple devices on a hardware and software level
Get to practice working on large CS projects relatively independently. Built greater expertise in the niche field that my project was in.
Project execution, front end development, research process
contour detection for cultural heritage sites
The skills you develop vary, depending on whether you decide to do research or build a software application.
Full stack development
I got to explore a topic in CS of my interest.
you get what you put into this class
Independent work on a CS oriented research project

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how I could take my project idea in any direction that I wanted to, although I was initially confused about what constraints I shouldve been worrying about.
As it was my senior project course, I don't have real feedback for how it can be improved as it was an independent study
Individual
Entirely dependent on your advisor. Like... 100% dependent.
Senior project is a nice course to take as long as you have a committed advisor (can be a prof or PhD)
I appreciated the opportunity to do self directed research with professor Zhong Shao. I think more help is needed in understanding the build system but I enjoyed my work other than that.
course is structured effectively
Not much to say here, as this is a required class. It also depends on your advisor.
Highly accomplished Professor
I think it needs to be more structured.

strengths: independence in choosing what you want to work on
weaknesses: no built in check in in between handing in your project proposal and the day that it is due

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how my advisor was always accessible through email and video call to answer any questions I had.
It was always very easy to meet with my advisor because of the virtual format although I would have preferred in-person meetings.
Individual project
Regular communication with your advisor every week
all succeeded effectively
Was not COVID affected
I think COVID-avoidance practices lready optimal.
not a ton of virtual engagement in this class if you didn't have an active advisor
Virtual meetings were convenient

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you would like to take initiative and spend a semester learning about a technical concept/building your own product independently.
Anyone who is a Computer Science major is required to and definitely should take this course.
Yes
It's required so uhhh.... I guess I'd recommend it yeah...
Yes because its required for the CS major and you learn a lot by doing research.
Yes! If you're interested in systems programming.
Required course
yes, it is a great experience to do a thesis

Try to find an advisor who will meet with you often. It makes this class much more bearable if you have frequent check-ins, and you're much more likely to make consistent progress on your project. It's somewhat obvious at the end which projects had time and effort put into them and which ones were just done in the last few weeks.
Does it matter? Whether or not I recommend the class isn't really salient to the fact that you have to take this to graduate.
Yes! Really enjoyable to build something
Yes, because you get to work on any topic you like and demonstrate your mastery of what you have learned in your undergrad studies.
choose a project your interested in and have a clear understanding of how much work youre getting yourself into

There is a lot of flexibility in the senior project which is great. I'm a CS&Math joint major and was able to pursue a personal project for credit. Also the math component is very chill, as is the presentation, and they just want to hear you talk about your project.

weekly meeting with advisor
